occurrences.line_text: Cride, Mercy mercy Sir vouchsafe to show
In so ritch weedes and seeming glorious show,
Whom seeing such, for dread he durst not show
Ne other grace vouchsafed them to show
With which the armes, that earst so bright did show,
That suddeine horror to faint harts did show;
And trembling with strange feare, did like an earthquake show.
For streight & narrow was the way, which he did show.
O pardon me, my soueraigne Lord, to show
Which I so much do vaunt, yet no where show,
And later times things more vnknowne shall show.
And yet the stone her semblance seemes to show,
Her once to show, ne court, nor dalliance,
And the faire land it selfe did plainly show.
Close vnderneath his shield, that scarce did show,
With that my shield I forth to her did show,
But if the weight of these thou canst not show,
And venge the shame, that she to Knights doth show.
That halfe her side it selfe did naked show,
Yet thus much friendship she to him did show,
And many pleasant trickes before her show,
Of pompous show, much more then she had told;
Would neuer more delight in painted show
Or Nymphes, or Faeries, or enchaunted show,
To make them louely or well fauoured show,
So be, O Queene, you equall fauour showe.
And doe in stead thereof mild curt'sie showe
All which he to the marchants sale did showe.
From that day forth he kyndnesse to her showed,
Brought in that mask of loue which late was showen:
By scattered shields was easie to be showen.
As their victorious deedes haue often showen,
And deck the world with their rich pompous showes;
That I in colourd showes may shadow it,
Ye will them all but fayned showes esteeme,
It showes, and with her brightnesse doth inflame
Not with such forged showes, as fitter beene
To them, that list, the worlds gay showes I leaue,
That all this worlds gay showes, which we admire,
They cannot finde that path, which first was showne,
And all her filthy feature open showne,
Or therein write to let his loue be showne;
And he thereby, where euer it in field was showne.
Cast how to salue, that both the custome showne
I haue so done, as she to me hath showne.
So when as fortune all her spight hath showne,
Now Bracidas let this likewise be showne.
As by his manners, in which plaine is showne
And did right noble deedes, the which elswhere are showne.
For in his shield, as thicke as stormie showre,
And poures it selfe forth in a stormy showre;
Like to thicke cloudes, that threat a stormy showre,
Ne the sharp Northerne wind thereon to showre,
And to that shed, to shrowd him from the showre,
Soone after that into a golden showre
Whilest through their rifts the ruddie bloud did showre
Couered with cloudie storme and bitter showre,
Heaping huge strokes, as thicke as showre of hayle,
With a sharpe showre of arrowes, which them staid,
The soring clouds into sad showres ymolt;
And not in outward shows, but inward thoughts defynd.
Showting for ioy, and still before their way
Graunt this, that when ye shred with fatall knife
For many other Nymphes he sore did shreek,
To Calepine, whose eares those shrieches shrill
With that a deadly shrieke she forth did throw,
Did shrieke alowd, that through the house it rong,
Thus whiles they spake, they heard a ruefull shrieke
She starting vp, began to shrieke aloud,
And shrieke aloud, that with the peoples voyce
And shrieked out, a thing vncomely for a knight.
With drearie shriekes did also her bewray;
And with sharpe shrilling shriekes doe bootlesse cry,
Does throw out thrilling shriekes, & shrieking cryes,
Her shrill outcryes and shriekes so loud did bray,
His ruefull shriekes and gronings, often tore
With percing shriekes, and many a dolefull lay;
With shrilling shriekes, Proteus abroad did roue,
But kicks, and squals, and shriekes for fell despight:
Does throw out thrilling shriekes, & shrieking cryes,
Shrieking his balefull note, which euer draue
With yelling outcries, and with shrieking sowne;
And shrieking Hububs them approching nere,
Some fearing shriekt, some being harmed hould,
Feebly she shriekt, but so feebly indeed,
Thereat he shriekt aloud, that with his cry
But afterwards she gan him soft to shrieue,
Downe in her lap she hid her face, and loudly shright.
Drawne with that Ladies loud and piteous shright,
That with their pitteous cryes, and yelling shrights,
That seem'd his shrikes would rend the brasen skie:
Lowde shriking him afflicted to the very sowle.
The whiles shril trompets & loud clarions sweetly playd.
And chearefull Chaunticlere with his note shrill
Her shrill outcryes and shriekes so loud did bray,
No bird, but did her shrill notes sweetly sing;
Which fame of her shrill trompet worthy reedes:
The Whistler shrill, that who so heares, doth dy,
They heard a noyse of many bagpipes shrill,
And when it ceast, shrill trompets loud did bray,
Triton his trompet shrill before them blew,
Of all that Tryumph. Then the trompets shrill
And caused streight a Trumpet loud to shrill,
Of his shrill cries him called to his aide.
And called oft with prayers loud and shrill,
To Calepine, whose eares those shrieches shrill
Then gan the bagpypes and the hornes to shrill,
Of a shrill pipe he playing heard on hight,
At last they heard a horne, that shrilled cleare
A shrilling trompet sownded from on hye,
And with sharpe shrilling shriekes doe bootlesse cry,
Was neuer wight, that heard that shrilling sound,
With shrilling shriekes, Proteus abroad did roue,
She heard a shrilling Trompet sound aloud,
That euer shrilling trumpet did resound;
Then shrilling trompets loudly gan to bray,
That Britomart heard not the shrilling sound,
And may not shrinck, though all the world do shake:
At last when as he found his force to shrincke,
Sith it is shrined in my Soueraines brest,
Whose corage when the feend perceiu'd to shrinke,
The bold Sansfoy shrinke vnderneath his speare;
Or gan to shrinke, or from the right to stray,
Ne backward shrinke, but as a stedfast towre,
Or that the flore to shrinke he did auyse,
But when he felt him shrinke, and come to ward,
He gan to shrinke, and somewhat to giue place,
Ne would him suffer once to shrinke asyde,
Decayd, and all his flesh shronk vp like withered flowres.
But all still shronke, and still he greater grew:
Were shronke into his iawes, as he did neuer dine.
From his reuengefull purpose shronke abacke,
And this faire couple eke to shroud the[m]selues were fain.
And found no place, where safe he shroud him might,
Her selfe to shroud, and pleasures to entreat.
In silence and in sleepe themselues did shroud,
Fresh shadowes, fit to shroud from sunny ray;
Seem'd vnder her protection him to shroud;
Which therein shrouded from the tempest dred,
The ioyous birdes shrouded in chearefull shade,
The whiles their flockes in shadowes shrouded bee,
That euery wight to shrowd it did constrain,
Vnder your beames I will me safely shrowd,
But answer none receiues: the darknes him does shrowd.
And now he doth himselfe in secret shrowd,
In which they shrowd the[m]selues from causelesse feare;
Therein to shrowd her sumptuous Belamoure,
And to that shed, to shrowd him from the showre,
To shrowd themselues, whiles sleepe their senses did inuade.
But for the present did her anger shrowd;
And shrowd their persons from that stormie stowre.
When euery creature shrowded is in sleepe;
And now in shade he shrowded yonder lies.
Where he is shrowded in security.
Doe hunt for shade, where shrowded they may lie,
Or else some woodman shrowded there from scorching sunne.
Warn'd man and beast in quiet rest be shrowded,
Had shrowded bene, she did from thraldome free;
There his three foes shrowded in guilefull shade,
Couered with shrubby woods, in which no way
Couer'd with boughes & shrubs from heauens light,
Couered with mossie shrubs, which spredding brode
For the thicke shrubs, which did them alwaies shade
Ne euer shruncke, ne euer sought to bayt
And had his staggering steede not shrunke for feare,
His feeble steps, which shrunke, when hard theron he lay.
And shrunken synewes of her chosen knight,
Faire Sir (quoth he) what man can shun the hap,
For who can shun the chaunce, that dest'ny doth ordaine?
Which he to shun, and stop vile enuies sting,
That euery one gan shun his dreadfull sight,
And shun his mightie strokes, gainst which no armes auayled.
Did shun the proofe thereof and it auoyded light.
Nought could he do, but shun the dred despight
Ne either sought the others strokes to shun,
His life attonce; who nought could do, but shun
Shun secresie, and talke in open sight:
His mery oaten pipe, but shund th'vnlucky ground.
That from thenceforth he shund the like to take,
And shund the marke, at which it should be ment,
And shund dishonor, which as death she feard:
That it she shund no lesse, then dread to die,
But she the way shund nathemore for thy,
That had he not it shun'd with heedfull vew,
He shund his strokes, where euer they did fall,
By all meanes shund to match with any forrein fere.
Ne shame he thought to shunne so hideous might:
Or shunne the death ordaynd by destinie?
To shunne the engin of his meant decay;
To shunne Rocke of Reproch, and it as death to dred.
All contrary, for she the right did shunne,
One day, as she to shunne the season whot,
And oft recuile to shunne his sharpe despight.
And greatly shunned manly exercise,
But lightly shunned it, and passing by,
His dreadfull souse auoydes, it shunning light,
The first, the gentle Shure that making way
Gan shut the dore. By this arriued there
And shut vp heauens windowes shyning wyde:
Whose gates he found fast shut, ne liuing wight
Thy life shut vp, for death so oft did call;
Which long time had bene shut, and out of hond
Did shut, and from behind it forth there lept
That readily they shut and open might.
She shut vp all her plaint in priuy griefe;
Was shut to all, which lodging did desire:
And shut vp fast within her prisons blind,
So none should be out shut, sith all of loues were fitted.
But Cambell thus did shut vp all in iest,
And for to shut vp all in friendly loue,
Shut vp her hauen, mard her marchants trade,
That it could not be shut, whilest Calidore
Long shut vp in the bud from heauens vew,
Did shut the gate against him in his face,
And shut vp all his plaint in priuy paine.
Her wretched life, shut vp in deadly shade,
And therein shut vp his blasphemous tong,
At last in close hart shutting vp her paine,
That shynd, like twinkling stars, with stons most pretious rare.
Informed in the mud, on which the Sunne hath shynd.
With fire not made to burne, but fairely for to shyne.
His feeble sence, and too exceeding shyne.
That like two Orient pearles, did purely shyne
As the great eye of heauen shyned bright,
So proud she shyned in her Princely state,
Aboue the shynie Cassiopeias chaire,
It was vpon a Sommers shynie day,
That shyning lampes in Ioues high house were light:
And shut vp heauens windowes shyning wyde:
And was for terrour more, all armd in shyning bras.
And shyning blade vnsheathd, with which he ran
In siluer sockets, shyning like the skyes,
The shyning glory of your soueraigne light,
Like to the Morne, when first her shyning face
Shyning with beauties light, and heauenly vertues grace.
Of the bright mettall, shyning like Sunne rayes;
Send forth their flames farre off to euery shyre,
Yet is no Fary borne, ne sib at all
And sib to great Orgolio, which was slaine
But rather ioyd to be, then seemen sich:
The fift had charge sicke persons to attend,
Hable to heale the sicke, and to reuiue the ded.
Of the sicke virgin, that her downe she layd
And choisest med'cine for sicke harts reliefe:
That mirrhour, wherein the sicke Damosell
And humid euening ill for sicke folkes cace:
Ere long so weake of limbe, and sicke of loue
For his sicke charge some harbour there to seeke;
To these sicke twaine, that now began to droupe,
Their hearts were sicke, their sides were sore, their feete were
During which space that she thus sicke did lie,
For safe conducting of his sickely Dame,
Thus hauing sayd, his sickely patients
And eke his Lady, though she sickely were,
A sodaine sickenesse, which her sore opprest,
Her sickenesse was not of the body but the mynde.
And to her feet betooke her doubtfull sickernesse.
But drew her selfe aside in sickernesse,
And soone forgot his former sickly paine;
Feare, sicknesse, age, losse, labour, sorrow, strife,
Those that with sicknesse were infected sore,
Besides, through sicknesse now so wan and weake,
Downe in a dale, hard by a forests side,
Forth spurred fast: adowne his coursers side
Their horned fronts so fierce on either side
And by my wretched louers side me pight,
Till seeing by her side the Lyon stand,
When his hot ryder spurd his chauffed side;
Thence to the hall, which was on euery side
Of Lordes and Ladies stood on euery side
And by his side rode loathsome Gluttony,
Two iron coffers hong on either side,
On th'other side in all mens open vew
That victory they dare not wish to either side.
And softly can embalme on euery side.
Which passing through, on euery side them stood
Of feends infernall flockt on euery side,
And rusticke horror all a side doe lay,
In secret shadow by a fountaine side:
To rest him selfe, foreby a fountaine side,
And by his side his steed the grassy forage ate.
Perce to my hart, and pas through euery side,
Which hong adowne his side in twisted gold,
Me seemed, by my side a royall Mayd
And by her side there sate a gentle paire
On either side disparted with his rod,
Where stretcht he lay vpon the sunny side
At last as chaunst them by a forest side
They stint their strife, and him assaile on euery side.
That her on either side do sore assay,
Fast by her side did sit the bold Sans-loy
Shall by to morrow by thy side be fond.
Proudly to prune, and set on euery side,
That seemd him to enflame on euery side:
That all his left side it did quite disarme;
And on the other side a pleasaunt groue
Vnto the other side of that wide strond,
And round about him lay on euery side
By that wayes side, there sate infernall Payne,
On thother side in one consort there sate,
On euery side they placed were along.
That drenched lay full deepe, vnder the Garden side.
So both attonce him charge on either side,
It seizd in his right side, and there the dint did stay.
On th'other side, in huge perplexity,
On either side, that neither mayle could hold,
And round about the porch on euery side
Did driue the Romanes to the weaker side,
By reason that the Captaines on her side,
So to the riuers side they both together far'd.
That castle to assaile on euery side,
On th'other side, th'assieged Castles ward
And many arrowes vnder his right side,
On th'other side an hideous Rocke is pight,
On th'other side, they saw that perilous Rocke,
On euery side floting the floods emong:
On th'other side they see that perilous Poole,
And calmy bay, on th'one side sheltered
On th'other side an high rocke toured still,
And strowed round about, and by his side
A large and spacious plaine, on euery side
And sore beset on euery side around,
And by his side the Goddesse groueling
And by her side her selfe she softly layd,
And chaungd her weary side, the better ease to take.
Where feeling one close couched by her side,
On th'other side, they saw the warlike Mayd
To gore her side, yet was the wound not deepe,
Ay ioyning foot to foot, and side to side,
Ay ioyning foot to foot, and side to side,
In the deare closet of her painefull side,
The wicked steele through his left side did glaunce;
And bold, as euer Squire that waited by knights side.
But from her louing side the tender babes to take.
And girt in with two walles on either side;
To an hilles side, which did to her bewray
She lightly vnto him adioyned side to syde;
Which houed close vnder a forrest side,
That it was he, which by her side did dwell,
And ech of them had ryding by his side
That had a goodly Ladie by his side,
Still watcht on euery side, of secret foes affrayd.
And at th'one side sixe iudges were dispos'd,
And on the other side in fresh aray,
Full many mightie strokes on either side
That nought mote stay the steele, till in his side
From daungers dread to ward his naked side,
Vnsure to whether side it would incline,
At last arriuing by the listes side,
And wise Cambina taking by her side
Which Blandamour had riding by his side:
Of his, on th'one; the rest on th'other side.
Gainst whom there singled from the other side
Staid not, till it arriued in his side.
On th'other side, full many a warlike swaine,
Till that there entred on the other side,
Vnder a steepe hilles side it placed was,
Vnder his side him nipt, that forst to wake,
An armed Knight vnder a forrest side,
With that she heard some one close by her side
By any Ladies side for Leman to haue laine.
And eke the Doue sate by the Faulcons side,
That all the while he by his side her bore,
For Paridell did take to Druons side,
And so from side to side till all the world it weet.
And so from side to side till all the world it weet.
On th'one side he, on th'other sate Delay,
On either side of her, two young men stood,
And by his side his Queene with coronall,
Therefore on either side she was sustained
An hundred times about the pit side fares,
That ill perhaps mote fall to either side.
Vncertaine whether had the better side:
And rudely stroke at him on euery side:
To which there did resort from euery side
Yet whether side was victor, note be ghest:
Fast bound on euery side with iron bands,
And heaped strokes so fast on euery side,
Basted with bends of gold on euery side,
She hewd, she foynd, she lasht, she laid on euery side.
That halfe her side it selfe did naked show,
The other ouer side the Bridge she cast
Vppon one side, and from his rootes doth reare.
And by the altars side her selfe to slumber plaste.
On th'other side her foe appeared soone in sight.
On euery side of his embatteld cart,
And made a griesly wound in his enriuen side.
From side to side they tost him here and there,
From side to side they tost him here and there,
Him when the damzell saw fast by her side,
The other on the other side, and neare them none.
He could his weapon shift from side to syde,
As if he would haue tottered to one side.
His side all bare and naked ouertooke,
None can haue tidings to assist her side.
By the way side being together set,
And by his side his hunters horne he hanging had.
On her faire feet by his horse side did pas
But comming to the riuers side, he found
He goth on foote all armed by her side,
Vnder the greenewoods side in sorie plight,
On euery side, and beat about him round;
Sought to encompasse him on euery side,
He wist not to which side him to addresse.
Led by a Carle and foole, which by her side did passe.
To giue him ground, and shift to euery side,
Who on the other side did seeme so farre
By his faire patients side with sorrowfull regret.
Least they should ioyne against the weaker side,
All which do him assayle on euery side,
And through their iron sides with cruell spies
My tender sides in this rough rynd embard,
The bold Semiramis, whose sides transfixt
Large floods of bloud adowne their sides did raile;
Their gory sides fresh bleeding fiercely fret,
And empty sides deceiued of their dew,
The which his naked sides he wrapt abouts;
Whose sides with dapled circles weren dight;
As gentle Hynd, whose sides with cruell steele
Till he his armes about her sides gan fold,
That cheekes with teares, and sides with bloud did all abound.
Againe through both the sides he strooke him quight,
That from his gorie sides the bloud did gush:
That both his sides were thrilled with the throw,
But both attonce on both sides him bestad,
And from their fruitfull sides sweet gum did drop,
Whose sides empurpled were with smiling red,
With roaring rage; and dashing on all sides,
Adowne their sides like litle riuers stremed,
In th'arm-pit full, that through both sides the wound appeard.
Oft chaunging sides, and oft new place electing,
And downe both sides two wide long eares did glow,
There gan they change their sides, and new parts take;
And all adowne their riuen sides did ronne.
And flancked both the bridges sides along,
And bake their sides vppon the cold hard stone,
Was fild with bloud, which from their sides did flow,
Which on both sides was then debating hard:
Which from their riuen sides forth gushed like a flood.
Hauing both sides through grypt with griesly wound.
And that this Lady, both whose sides are pearst
So sore her sides, so much her wounds did bleede:
That from his sides some noble chyld should rize,
Their hearts were sicke, their sides were sore, their feete were
Her tender sides, her bellie white and clere,
But she whose sides before with secret wound
From lofty siege began these words aloud to sound.
A stately siege of soueraigne maiestye;
And with long siege vs in this castle hould:
What warre so cruell, or what siege so sore,
And lay strong siege about it far and wide.
Did lay strong siege, and battailous assault,
Against that Castle restlesse siege did lay,
Who long before the ten yeares siege of Troy,
Or daily siege through dispuruayance long,
Continuall siege vnto her gentle hart;
For I resolue this siege not to giue ouer,
And fast imprisoned in sieged fort.
Into a long large chamber, which was sield
That cropt the branches of the sient base,
And with most painefull pangs to sigh and sob,
And sigh full sore, to heare the miserie,
Full many a night for her did sigh and grone:
But inly sigh'd. At last the royall Mayd
Therewith he sigh'd, and turning him aside,
He sigh'd, he sobd, he swownd, he perdy dyde,
Shame lowrd, Repentance sigh'd, Reproch did scould;
Wherewith she sighed soft, as if his case she rewd.
Thereat she sighed deepe, and after thus complaynd.
She sighed soft, that none so bestiall,
With that he sighed deepe for inward tyne:
What cared she, who sighed for her sore,
And sighes, and grones, and euermore does steepe
But wordes, and lookes, and sighes she did abhore,
With sighes, and sobs, and plaints, & piteous griefe,
In stead thereof sad sighes, and sorrowes deepe
Whence forth it breakes in sighes and anguish rife,
But with soft sighes, and louely semblaunces,
And did the rest with grieuous sighes suppresse,
Those Pensifenesse did moue; and Sighes the bellows weare.
As women wont, but with deepe sighes, and singulfs few.
Then sighing soft, I learne that litle sweet
And looking louely, and oft sighing sore,
Thereat she sighing softly, had no powre
And sighing sore, at length him thus bespake;
Then sighing softly sore, and inly deepe,
Then sighing soft awhile, at last she thus:
Then sighing sore, It is not long (said he)
Sighing and sobbing sore, as if the paine
And sighing inly deepe, her thus bespake;
But Scudamour then sighing deepe, thus saide,
Yet inly groning deepe and sighing oft,
Aye me (sayd then Serena sighing sore)
Who sighing sore, as if her hart in twaine
Ah well away (sayd he then sighing sore)
That detestable sight him much amazde,
So liuely, and so like in all mens sight,
Was nigh beguiled with so goodly sight:
All cleane dismayd to see so vncouth sight,
And bitter anguish of his guiltie sight,
